step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: UNMOUNTABLE_BOOT_VOLUME - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during gpu / display system errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: HYPERVISOR_ERROR happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code HYPERVISOR_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during virtualization / hypervisor errors.
cause: Hypervisor or virtualization layer fault; driver or VM misconfiguration.
step_1: Disable virtualization features temporarily (Hyper-V) and test if BSOD persists.
step_2: Update virtualization software (Hyper-V, VMware) and host drivers.
step_3: Ensure nested virtualization or emulator settings are compatible with host hardware.
step_4: Check for known issues with specific VM images and apply recommended patches.
step_5: If virtualization layer is faulty, avoid running VMs until host stability is confirmed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: HYPERVISOR_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code CLEAN_BOOT_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CLEAN_BOOT_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CLEAN_BOOT_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows 0x124 and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code 0x124; system may reboot or hang. Observed during bios / firmware / overclock errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS to default settings and disable any overclocking profiles.
step_2: Update BIOS/UEFI firmware to the latest stable version from vendor (follow instructions carefully).
step_3: Check CPU microcode updates and vendor advisories for known issues.
step_4: If custom BIOS settings caused instability, revert the changes and test.
step_5: If firmware update fails or causes issues, contact vendor support for recovery steps.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: 0x124 - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code CLOCK_WATCHDOG_TIMEOUT.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CLOCK_WATCHDOG_TIMEOUT; system may reboot or hang. Observed during cpu / processor errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS settings to defaults and disable overclocking to test stability.
step_2: Ensure CPU cooler is properly seated and thermal paste applied; monitor temperatures.
step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.

user_error_text: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: THREAD_STUCK_IN_DEVICE_DRIVER appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code THREAD_STUCK_IN_DEVICE_DRIVER; system may reboot or hang. Observed during gpu / display system errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: THREAD_STUCK_IN_DEVICE_DRIVER - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get BAD_POOL_HEADER.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code BAD_POOL_HEADER; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.

step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.

symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

symptoms: Blue screen with stop code STATUS_SYSTEM_PROCESS_TERMINATED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: STATUS_SYSTEM_PROCESS_TERMINATED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

symptoms: Blue screen with stop code SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code UNEXPECTED_KERNEL_MODE_TRAP.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code UNEXPECTED_KERNEL_MODE_TRAP; system may reboot or hang. Observed during cpu / processor errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS settings to defaults and disable overclocking to test stability.
step_2: Ensure CPU cooler is properly seated and thermal paste applied; monitor temperatures.
step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.
step_4: Update BIOS/firmware to latest vendor version to fix microcode issues.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support — replace motherboard/CPU if needed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: UNEXPECTED_KERNEL_MODE_TRAP - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: BOOT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code BOOT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: BOOT_DEVICE_NOT_FOUND - BugCheck recorded in system log.

cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during gpu / display system errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code STATUS_SYSTEM_PROCESS_TERMINATED.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code STATUS_SYSTEM_PROCESS_TERMINATED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: STATUS_SYSTEM_PROCESS_TERMINATED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows KERNEL_DATA_INPAGE_ERROR and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_DATA_INPAGE_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_DATA_INPAGE_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows ACPI_BIOS_ERROR and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code ACPI_BIOS_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during bios / firmware / overclock errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS to default settings and disable any overclocking profiles.
step_2: Update BIOS/UEFI firmware to the latest stable version from vendor (follow instructions carefully).
step_3: Check CPU microcode updates and vendor advisories for known issues.
step_4: If custom BIOS settings caused instability, revert the changes and test.
step_5: If firmware update fails or causes issues, contact vendor support for recovery steps.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during cpu / processor errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS settings to defaults and disable overclocking to test stability.
step_2: Ensure CPU cooler is properly seated and thermal paste applied; monitor temperatures.
step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.
step_4: Update BIOS/firmware to latest vendor version to fix microcode issues.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support — replace motherboard/CPU if needed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: VIDEO_SCHEDULER_INTERNAL_ERROR happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIDEO_SCHEDULER_INTERNAL_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during gpu / display system errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIDEO_SCHEDULER_INTERNAL_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during virtualization / hypervisor errors.
cause: Hypervisor or virtualization layer fault; driver or VM misconfiguration.
step_1: Disable virtualization features temporarily (Hyper-V) and test if BSOD persists.
step_2: Update virtualization software (Hyper-V, VMware) and host drivers.
step_3: Ensure nested virtualization or emulator settings are compatible with host hardware.
step_4: Check for known issues with specific VM images and apply recommended patches.
step_5: If virtualization layer is faulty, avoid running VMs until host stability is confirmed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: CRITICAL_STRUCTURE_CORRUPTION happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_STRUCTURE_CORRUPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get FAT_FILE_SYSTEM.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code FAT_FILE_SYSTEM; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: FAT_FILE_SYSTEM - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: BAD_POOL_HEADER happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code BAD_POOL_HEADER; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: BAD_POOL_HEADER - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during cpu / processor errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Reset BIOS settings to defaults and disable overclocking to test stability.
step_2: Ensure CPU cooler is properly seated and thermal paste applied; monitor temperatures.
step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.
step_4: Update BIOS/firmware to latest vendor version to fix microcode issues.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support — replace motherboard/CPU if needed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: SYSTEM_THREAD_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during hardware malfunction / compatibility errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Power down and inspect internal components for loose cables or obvious damage.
step_2: Check system temperatures in BIOS/UEFI and ensure fans/heatsinks are working.
step_3: Run vendor hardware diagnostics (built-in diagnostics or bootable tools).
step_4: If available, swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units to isolate failure.
step_5: Backup data and replace failing hardware as indicated by diagnostics.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows CLEAN_BOOT_FAILURE and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CLEAN_BOOT_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CLEAN_BOOT_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during hardware malfunction / compatibility errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Power down and inspect internal components for loose cables or obvious damage.
step_2: Check system temperatures in BIOS/UEFI and ensure fans/heatsinks are working.
step_3: Run vendor hardware diagnostics (built-in diagnostics or bootable tools).
step_4: If available, swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units to isolate failure.
step_5: Backup data and replace failing hardware as indicated by diagnostics.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during bios / firmware / overclock errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Reset BIOS to default settings and disable any overclocking profiles.
step_2: Update BIOS/UEFI firmware to the latest stable version from vendor (follow instructions carefully).
step_3: Check CPU microcode updates and vendor advisories for known issues.
step_4: If custom BIOS settings caused instability, revert the changes and test.
step_5: If firmware update fails or causes issues, contact vendor support for recovery steps.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: SYSTEM_SERVICE_EXCEPTION appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code SYSTEM_SERVICE_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: SYSTEM_SERVICE_EXCEPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during virtualization / hypervisor errors.
cause: Hypervisor or virtualization layer fault; driver or VM misconfiguration.
step_1: Disable virtualization features temporarily (Hyper-V) and test if BSOD persists.
step_2: Update virtualization software (Hyper-V, VMware) and host drivers.
step_3: Ensure nested virtualization or emulator settings are compatible with host hardware.
step_4: Check for known issues with specific VM images and apply recommended patches.
step_5: If virtualization layer is faulty, avoid running VMs until host stability is confirmed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get KERNEL_BOOT_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_BOOT_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_BOOT_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows 0x124 and restarts immediately.

cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.

step_2: Update BIOS/UEFI firmware to the latest stable version from vendor (follow instructions carefully).
step_3: Check CPU microcode updates and vendor advisories for known issues.
step_4: If custom BIOS settings caused instability, revert the changes and test.
step_5: If firmware update fails or causes issues, contact vendor support for recovery steps.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during cpu / processor errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Reset BIOS settings to defaults and disable overclocking to test stability.
step_2: Ensure CPU cooler is properly seated and thermal paste applied; monitor temperatures.
step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.
step_4: Update BIOS/firmware to latest vendor version to fix microcode issues.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support — replace motherboard/CPU if needed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_IRQL_NOT_LESS_OR_EQUAL - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: SESSION_HAS_VALID_POOL_ON_EXIT appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code SESSION_HAS_VALID_POOL_ON_EXIT; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: SESSION_HAS_VALID_POOL_ON_EXIT - BugCheck recorded in system log.

symptoms: Blue screen with stop code STATUS_SYSTEM_PROCESS_TERMINATED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.

symptoms: Blue screen with stop code MICROCODE_REVISION_MISMATCH; system may reboot or hang. Observed during bios / firmware / overclock errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS to default settings and disable any overclocking profiles.
step_2: Update BIOS/UEFI firmware to the latest stable version from vendor (follow instructions carefully).
step_3: Check CPU microcode updates and vendor advisories for known issues.
step_4: If custom BIOS settings caused instability, revert the changes and test.
step_5: If firmware update fails or causes issues, contact vendor support for recovery steps.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: MICROCODE_REVISION_MISMATCH - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code THREAD_STUCK_IN_DEVICE_DRIVER.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code THREAD_STUCK_IN_DEVICE_DRIVER; system may reboot or hang. Observed during gpu / display system errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: THREAD_STUCK_IN_DEVICE_DRIVER - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIDEO_TDR_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: INTERNAL_POWER_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: CRITICAL_STRUCTURE_CORRUPTION appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_STRUCTURE_CORRUPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during security / antivirus / malware-triggered crashes.
cause: Security software or malware interfering with kernel processes.
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and temporarily disable third-party antivirus/security software to test.
step_2: Run full antivirus and anti-malware scans from bootable rescue media if needed.
step_3: Check recent security software updates and roll back if BSOD started after an update.
step_4: Ensure security tools are vendor-approved and compatible with your OS version.
step_5: If malware suspected, backup data and perform a clean install after cleaning the system.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_STRUCTURE_CORRUPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during virtualization / hypervisor errors.
cause: Hypervisor or virtualization layer fault; driver or VM misconfiguration.
step_1: Disable virtualization features temporarily (Hyper-V) and test if BSOD persists.
step_2: Update virtualization software (Hyper-V, VMware) and host drivers.
step_3: Ensure nested virtualization or emulator settings are compatible with host hardware.
step_4: Check for known issues with specific VM images and apply recommended patches.
step_5: If virtualization layer is faulty, avoid running VMs until host stability is confirmed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIRTUALIZATION_EXCEPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during cpu / processor errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS settings to defaults and disable overclocking to test stability.
step_2: Ensure CPU cooler is properly seated and thermal paste applied; monitor temperatures.
step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.
step_4: Update BIOS/firmware to latest vendor version to fix microcode issues.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support — replace motherboard/CPU if needed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during hardware malfunction / compatibility errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Power down and inspect internal components for loose cables or obvious damage.
step_2: Check system temperatures in BIOS/UEFI and ensure fans/heatsinks are working.
step_3: Run vendor hardware diagnostics (built-in diagnostics or bootable tools).
step_4: If available, swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units to isolate failure.
step_5: Backup data and replace failing hardware as indicated by diagnostics.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: WHEA_UNCORRECTABLE_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM - BugCheck recorded in system log.

cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.

user_error_text: My PC shows BAD_POOL_HEADER and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code BAD_POOL_HEADER; system may reboot or hang. Observed during memory & ram errors.
cause: Possible faulty RAM, memory corruption, or driver accessing bad memory.
step_1: Power off and reseat RAM modules; if multiple, try one module at a time to isolate faulty RAM.
step_2: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) and follow results after reboot.
step_3: Update motherboard chipset and memory-related drivers from vendor website.
step_4: If errors persist, test with MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_5: Backup important data and plan to replace failing memory modules if diagnostics report faults.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: BAD_POOL_HEADER - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

step_3: Run CPU stress tests (short) in a controlled environment to check stability.
step_4: Update BIOS/firmware to latest vendor version to fix microcode issues.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support — replace motherboard/CPU if needed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KMODE_EXCEPTION_NOT_HANDLED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM; system may reboot or hang. Observed during boot & storage device errors.
cause: Bootloader or disk access issues — possible corrupted filesystem or failing drive.
step_1: Check BIOS/UEFI boot order and ensure correct system drive is selected.
step_2: Boot into Recovery Environment and run Startup Repair.
step_3: From recovery command prompt, run `chkdsk C: /f /r` to repair disk errors.
step_4: If Boot Configuration Data is corrupted, rebuild BCD using `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_5: If drive shows SMART errors, backup data immediately and replace the drive.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during critical system process failures.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Restart and boot into Safe Mode (Hold Shift while clicking Restart → Troubleshoot → Startup Settings).
step_2: Run System File Checker: open Command Prompt as admin and run `sfc /scannow`.
step_3: Run DISM to repair the Windows image: `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_4: Check Device Manager for recently installed drivers and roll back or update suspicious drivers.
step_5: If issue persists, run chkdsk on system drive and consider a system restore to earlier point.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: KERNEL_SECURITY_CHECK_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: I keep getting a blue screen with code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE; system may reboot or hang. Observed during driver failures.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Boot into Safe Mode and uninstall the suspected device driver via Device Manager.
step_2: Use the vendor's official driver package to reinstall the correct driver (avoid generic drivers).
step_3: For GPU drivers, use DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller) in Safe Mode then install fresh drivers.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if the BSOD began after an update.
step_5: If problem continues, test hardware on another machine to isolate driver vs hardware.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: DRIVER_POWER_STATE_FAILURE - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: VIDEO_SCHEDULER_INTERNAL_ERROR happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code VIDEO_SCHEDULER_INTERNAL_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during gpu / display system errors.
cause: Faulty or incompatible device driver (GPU, network, chipset).
step_1: Update or roll back GPU drivers; for crashes use DDU to remove old drivers first.
step_2: Ensure the GPU is properly seated and auxiliary power connectors are attached.
step_3: Test with onboard graphics (if available) or another monitor/cable to isolate the display path.
step_4: Lower GPU clocks to default if overclocked and test for stability.
step_5: Check GPU temperatures and run GPU stress test briefly to verify stability.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: VIDEO_SCHEDULER_INTERNAL_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED happens randomly while using the computer.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during power & sleep / hibernate errors.
cause: Power state or driver transition failure; issues with sleep/hibernate drivers.
step_1: Disconnect all peripherals and try booting to rule out external device issues.
step_2: Update power management and chipset drivers from the vendor site.
step_3: Check Windows power plan settings and disable fast startup temporarily.
step_4: Inspect battery (laptops) or PSU connections; try a different power adapter or PSU if possible.
step_5: If hibernate/sleep triggers crashes, disable hibernate and test again.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: Every time I try to boot, I get HYPERVISOR_ERROR.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code HYPERVISOR_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during virtualization / hypervisor errors.
cause: Hypervisor or virtualization layer fault; driver or VM misconfiguration.
step_1: Disable virtualization features temporarily (Hyper-V) and test if BSOD persists.
step_2: Update virtualization software (Hyper-V, VMware) and host drivers.
step_3: Ensure nested virtualization or emulator settings are compatible with host hardware.
step_4: Check for known issues with specific VM images and apply recommended patches.
step_5: If virtualization layer is faulty, avoid running VMs until host stability is confirmed.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: HYPERVISOR_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: My PC shows MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION and restarts immediately.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION; system may reboot or hang. Observed during hardware malfunction / compatibility errors.
cause: Possible hardware failure (CPU, PSU, motherboard) or overheating/overclock instability.
step_1: Power down and inspect internal components for loose cables or obvious damage.
step_2: Check system temperatures in BIOS/UEFI and ensure fans/heatsinks are working.
step_3: Run vendor hardware diagnostics (built-in diagnostics or bootable tools).
step_4: If available, swap suspect components (PSU/RAM) with known-good units to isolate failure.
step_5: Backup data and replace failing hardware as indicated by diagnostics.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: MACHINE_CHECK_EXCEPTION - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED; system may reboot or hang. Observed during file system / os corruption.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Run `sfc /scannow` to repair system files and then `DISM /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth`.
step_2: Check Event Viewer for specific errors and identify affected system files.
step_3: If the corruption is severe, perform an in-place upgrade/repair using Media Creation Tool.
step_4: Backup user data and consider a clean install if several repairs fail.
step_5: Keep filesystem backups and enable system protection for future restores.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: CRITICAL_SERVICE_FAILED - BugCheck recorded in system log.

user_error_text: ACPI_BIOS_ERROR appears after a recent update and Windows won't stay on.
symptoms: Blue screen with stop code ACPI_BIOS_ERROR; system may reboot or hang. Observed during bios / firmware / overclock errors.
cause: System file corruption, driver issues, or hardware faults.
step_1: Reset BIOS to default settings and disable any overclocking profiles.
step_2: Update BIOS/UEFI firmware to the latest stable version from vendor (follow instructions carefully).
step_3: Check CPU microcode updates and vendor advisories for known issues.
step_4: If custom BIOS settings caused instability, revert the changes and test.
step_5: If firmware update fails or causes issues, contact vendor support for recovery steps.
verification: System boots and runs without repeating the BSOD for at least 10 minutes.
log_snippet: ACPI_BIOS_ERROR - BugCheck recorded in system log.
